text: it's a real pleasure to be here today
this is a blurry photograph that I
wanted to start off it's of me in my
formative days I'm as you heard from
Zimbabwe and I was born to coffee and
tea farmers and I think it was my early
experience with porous international
borders that led me to consider the wide
world is my backyard and I now have
lived and worked in five continents
which has included to developing
countries in Bob way and more recently
Nepal my particular background and
intersection with this event is as a
neuroscientist and a visual artist and
I'm going to leave a lot of the
innovation discussion of inventions to
the people that are coming after me but
I wanted to set some some of the stage
to that so I became my particular
interest is in vision and I became
interested especially in color through
my obsession with painting and this is a
photograph of me I take my paints with
me virtually everywhere I go this is a
photograph of me with a young onlooker
and the grand square in Mexico City and
that's the extent of my innovation
that's an ice cream bucket lid which I
use as my palate painting making
pictures gives you an opportunity for
extended viewing which has afforded me a
chance to appreciate this magnificent
thing that our visual system does our
eyes are constantly being bombarded with
light and somehow our brains our eyes
and brains are able to reconstruct all
of that information into something
coherent and meaningful and this process
is not trivial our eyes our brains don't
work like photographic film developing
that as a camera and and photographic
apparatus might instead there's some
sophisticated neural computations that
take place and to illustrate this point
I wanted to show this wonderful visual
illusion from beau lotto the although it
doesn't seem that way the blue squares
in the left yellow cube are actually
physically identical to the yellow
squares
this cube and I can prove that by taking
exactly the same slide and then just
cover it with a mask so here I'll go
back so you can see that for yourself
here it's exactly the same slide so what
this tells us is that our experience of
the world is context-dependent it's
somehow deeply profoundly
context-dependent and my neuroscience
examines what the brains mechanisms are
that that bring that about what I'm also
interested in is what these brain
mechanisms tell us about the process of
making art and they must impact the
process of making art when you're mixing
colors in the studio as Cezanne might
have been you're mixing color that Otto
in a white context that ultimately is
going to appear in a very different
context and how do you account for the
change in color appearance that is to
take place what's curious about his
method is that he at no point draws an
outline and then fills it in which is a
violation at the very tenant we were all
taught with coloring in books showing
that this this process of his process
violates in some sense our expectations
so how does he do it one of the things
that he does which is the thing that I
really wanted to get across today is he
engages in trial and error he actually
uses his own sensory apparatus as a
feedback device so that he gets to be
the one who decides whether or not the
color is successful or not and he can
change his mind continuously and it's
this process of trial and error that i
think is at the heart not just of art
making art but also of successful
science even though in high schools were
often taught that science follows this
very strict scientific method where
they're well established rules and you
follow those rules and then you
accomplish those rules and you publish a
science paper at the end of it well it
turns out as you'll hear today that a
lot of science in fact I would argue the
most successful science doesn't work
according to well described rules it
happens as a result of accidents when
those rules are broken and the
attentiveness of the observers so one of
my I think one of the other hallmarks of
successful science is that the
scientists are often deeply moved by the
sensual is in an essential way by the
materials they work with
my mentor the neurobiologist David Hubel
has described his joy at machining brass
and it was his pleasure in working with
tungsten that led him to invent the
tungsten micro electrode which has
revolutionized systems neuroscience here
I've depicted him in his long term
colleague Torsten Wiesel pulling back
the proverbial curtain on the black box
that is the the brain figuring out what
the neural mechanisms of a vision are
and if you go back and you look at their
their notebooks what you see is not this
rigorous scientific method but rather
something more exploratory more sort of
innovative in in its approach less well
defined these guys are not doing high
school science reports they're tackling
difficult problems than they're
motivated by their passion for discovery
and that passion there's no rules that
guide them in that passion this process
of innovation is one that is familiar to
two artists it's in fact a process
that's adopted a lot of art studios this
is a collection of paintings put
together by Dora Maar of Picasso's work
and what this collection shows is that
the sum of the parts is more important
than any one single painting what
Picasso is doing in his process is
iteratively working through different
ideas he's not solving one particular
problem and I think that theme that
science itself works in the same way
you'll you'll hear a little bit about
today so I've been exploring these ideas
I was asked to show a little bit of my
own art I make these I do a lot of stuff
in addition to watercolours but one of
the things I do is I make these glass
and silk boxes which adhere to a set or
at least attempt to adhere to a set of
constraints much like the kinds of rules
that Sol LeWitt developed or Agnes
Martin or Donald Judd but instead of
just advancing a minimalist agenda what
I'm interested in is the unavoidable
consequence that happens when you make
stuff it breaks the rules are violated
I'm interested in the difference between
what you think the thing will look like
the thing pictured in the mind's eye
versus what actually is there solidly
and real in front of you and I think
that concern places places are role the
sensory and cognitive mechanisms
squarely at the heart of of the creative
process which is powerful because our
brains are the most sophisticated neural
the most sophisticated computational
devices in the universe there's just a
high resolution one of those so this
process of discovery you know you don't
have to go far and you're going to hear
a lot about it today it can be very
sophisticated and oftentimes it can be
very elegant this is a picture of a from
karl deisseroth group where they've
managed to engineer a mouse so that it
expresses photosensitive pigment inside
the neurons in the brain and using a
light probe you can then turn on those
cells or turn them off this technical
innovation isn't the product of some
scientific method it's some guys almost
science science fiction crazy idea that
happened to work and it's now the the
engine driving a lot of biomedical
research that's already provided a lot
of insight into neurological diseases
like Parkinson's disease or these ideas
can be very simple this is a painting I
made when I was in Nepal and these are
women who have developed a headdress
sack that leverages the powerful muscles
of the shoulder to carry away bricks and
I think what you'll hear about today is
a lot of these oftentimes as karl said
very simple innovations that are
actually pretty sophisticated in in the
kinds of creative process that led led
to them and I wanted to end with a
little personal story from Zimbabwe
during the Rhodesian Civil War the the
the guerrillas would come onto our
families tea estate and would plant
landmines between the between the tea
bushes and my uncle in order to try and
solve this problem make the environment
safe for the workers develop this device
which consisted of a giant drum that he
would push at the end of a pole down the
rows of tea in the morning and it would
detonate the landmines and send the drum
flying harmlessly into the air and
create a safe path for the workers to
work behind them a very simple
innovation but I think it speaks to the
heart of a lot of a lot of the issues
that you're going to hear about this
evening from my point of view I hope I
could rub off on you to think about
these things not just as you know
science technical innovation out there
on one hand but these innovators they
really are the process of their
innovation really is art
